012package org.postgresql.pljava.example.polyglot;
013
014import java.nio.ByteBuffer;
015import java.nio.CharBuffer;
016import java.nio.charset.CharacterCodingException;
017import static java.nio.charset.StandardCharsets.US_ASCII;
018
019import java.sql.SQLException;
020import java.sql.SQLSyntaxErrorException;
021
022import java.util.Base64;
023import java.util.BitSet;
024import java.util.Objects;
025import static java.util.Optional.ofNullable;
026
027import static java.util.stream.Collectors.toList;
028
029import org.postgresql.pljava.PLJavaBasedLanguage.InlineBlocks;
030import org.postgresql.pljava.PLJavaBasedLanguage.Routines;
031import org.postgresql.pljava.PLJavaBasedLanguage.Routine;
032import org.postgresql.pljava.PLJavaBasedLanguage.Template;
033import org.postgresql.pljava.PLJavaBasedLanguage.Triggers;
034import org.postgresql.pljava.PLJavaBasedLanguage.TriggerFunction;
035import org.postgresql.pljava.PLJavaBasedLanguage.TriggerTemplate;
036
037import org.postgresql.pljava.TargetList.Projection;
038
039import org.postgresql.pljava.annotation.SQLAction;
040
041import org.postgresql.pljava.model.Attribute;
042import org.postgresql.pljava.model.ProceduralLanguage;
043import org.postgresql.pljava.model.ProceduralLanguage.PLJavaBased;
044import org.postgresql.pljava.model.RegProcedure;
045import org.postgresql.pljava.model.RegProcedure.Call;
046import org.postgresql.pljava.model.RegProcedure.Lookup;
047import org.postgresql.pljava.model.Trigger;
048import org.postgresql.pljava.model.TupleDescriptor;
049import org.postgresql.pljava.model.TupleTableSlot;
050
051/**
052 * Example of a procedural language implemented atop PL/Java.
053 *<p>
054 * Glot64 has a couple of features rarely found in a PostgreSQL PL. First, you
055 * can't use it to do anything, other than print some text to standard output.
056 * That's the server's standard output, which you probably won't even see unless
057 * running the server with standard output to your terminal, as you might run a
058 * test instance under PL/Java's test harness. On a production server, what is
059 * written to standard output may well go nowhere at all, and then it may truly
060 * be said your Glot64 routines do nothing at all.
061 *<p>
062 * Second, Glot64 has the rare property that the compiled form of its code is
063 * easier to read than the source. That's because when you
064 * {@code CREATE FUNCTION} or {@code CREATE PROCEDURE} in Glot64, you write
065 * the {@code AS} part in Base64. It gets 'compiled' by decoding it to ASCII.
066 * (Unless it is malformed Base64 or doesn't decode to ASCII. Then your routine
067 * gets rejected by the validator. Better luck next time.) Then, when you call
068 * the function or procedure, the 'compiled' code is written to standard output.
069 * Therefore,
070 *<pre><code>
071 * CREATE FUNCTION hello() RETURNS void
072 *   LANGUAGE glot64
073 *   AS 'SGVsbG8sIHdvcmxkIQo=';
074 *</code></pre>
075 * defines a function that writes "Hello, world!" when you call it.
076 *<p>
077 * However, Glot64 writes several other things to standard output ahead of the
078 * output of the routine itself. That is the real purpose: to illustrate how
079 * PL/Java's language handler API is arranged, and how the information about the
080 * parameters and result type (or types) will be presented to your code.
081 *<p>
082 * You can declare a Glot64 function or procedure with any number and types of
083 * parameters and return type (or {@code OUT} parameters). Because your routine
084 * will not use any of the arguments or produce any result, it doesn't care how
085 * they are declared. By declaring Glot64 functions in several different ways,
086 * you can see, in the output messages, how the API presents that information.
087 */
088@SQLAction(requires = "pljavahandler language", install = {
089"CREATE OR REPLACE FUNCTION javatest.glot64_validator(oid)" +
090" RETURNS void" +
091" LANGUAGE pljavahandler AS 'org.postgresql.pljava.example.polyglot.Glot64'",
092
093"COMMENT ON FUNCTION javatest.glot64_validator(oid) IS " +
094"'Validator function for the glot64 procedural language'",
095
096"CREATE LANGUAGE glot64" +
097" HANDLER sqlj.pljavaDispatchRoutine" +
098" INLINE  sqlj.pljavaDispatchInline" +
099" VALIDATOR javatest.glot64_validator",
100
101"COMMENT ON LANGUAGE glot64 IS " +
102"'The glot64 procedural language, which is implemented atop PL/Java, " +
103"and supports functions, procedures, and inline code blocks'",
104
105"CREATE FUNCTION javatest.hello() RETURNS void" +
106" LANGUAGE glot64 AS 'SGVsbG8sIHdvcmxkIQo='",
107
108"CREATE FUNCTION javatest.hello(anyelement) RETURNS anyelement" +
109" LANGUAGE glot64 AS 'SGVsbG8sIHdvcmxkIQo='",
110
111"CREATE FUNCTION javatest.hello(a int4, b int4, OUT c int2, OUT d int2)" +
112" LANGUAGE glot64 AS 'SGVsbG8sIHdvcmxkIQo='",
113
114"CREATE FUNCTION javatest.hello(text, VARIADIC \"any\") RETURNS text[]" +
115" LANGUAGE glot64 AS 'SGVsbG8sIHdvcmxkIQo='",
116
117"CREATE PROCEDURE javatest.say_hello()" +
118" LANGUAGE glot64 AS 'SGVsbG8sIHdvcmxkIQo='",
119
120"DO LANGUAGE glot64 'SGVsbG8sIHdvcmxkIQo='",
121
122"SELECT javatest.hello()",
123
124"SELECT javatest.hello()",
125
126"SELECT javatest.hello(42)",
127
128"SELECT javatest.hello(n) FROM generate_series(1,3) AS t(n)",
129
130"CALL javatest.say_hello()",
131
132"CREATE FUNCTION javatest.glot64_trigger() RETURNS trigger" +
133" LANGUAGE glot64 AS 'dHJpZ2dlciBkZW1vCg=='",
134
135"CREATE TRIGGER g64_as_d AFTER DELETE ON javatest.username_test" +
136" REFERENCING OLD TABLE AS oldone FOR EACH STATEMENT" +
137" EXECUTE FUNCTION javatest.glot64_trigger('ab', 'cd')",
138
139"CREATE CONSTRAINT TRIGGER g64_ar_iu AFTER INSERT OR UPDATE" +
140" ON javatest.username_test FOR EACH ROW" +
141" EXECUTE FUNCTION javatest.glot64_trigger('ef', 'gh')",
142
143"INSERT INTO javatest.username_test VALUES ('Wilhelm Glot', '64')",
144
145"UPDATE javatest.username_test SET name = 'Glot, Wilhelm'" +
146" WHERE username = '64'",
147
148"DELETE FROM javatest.username_test WHERE username = '64'"
149}, remove = {
150"DROP TRIGGER g64_ar_iu ON javatest.username_test",
151"DROP TRIGGER g64_as_d ON javatest.username_test",
152"DROP FUNCTION javatest.glot64_trigger()",
153"DROP PROCEDURE javatest.say_hello()",
154"DROP FUNCTION javatest.hello(text,VARIADIC \"any\")",
155"DROP FUNCTION javatest.hello(int4,int4)",
156"DROP FUNCTION javatest.hello(anyelement)",
157"DROP FUNCTION javatest.hello()",
158"DO LANGUAGE glot64 'QnllIGJ5ZSEK'",
159"DROP LANGUAGE glot64",
160"DROP FUNCTION javatest.glot64_validator(oid)"
161})
162public class Glot64 implements InlineBlocks, Routines, Triggers
163{
164    private final ProceduralLanguage pl;
165
166    /**
167     * There must be a public constructor with a {@code ProceduralLanguage}
168     * parameter.
169     *<p>
170     * The parameter can be ignored, or used to determine the name, oid,
171     * accessibility, or other details of the declared PostgreSQL language
172     * your handler class has been instantiated for.
173     */
174    public Glot64(ProceduralLanguage pl)
175    {
176        this.pl = pl;
177    }
178
179    /**
180     * The sole method needed to implement inline code blocks.
181     *<p>
182     * This one merely writes the 'compiled' source text to standard output.
183     * @param inlineSource the source text to be executed as the inline code
184     * block.
185     * @param atomic true if top-level transaction control must be disallowed
186     * within the block. PL/Java will already handle propagating this value to
187     * underlying PostgreSQL SPI calls your code might make, but it is also
188     * available here in case your language has compilation choices it can make
189     * based on that information.
190     */
191    @Override
192    public void execute(String inlineSource, boolean atomic) throws SQLException
193    {
194        System.out.printf("%s inline code block (atomic: %s):\n", pl, atomic)
195            .print(compile(inlineSource));
196    }
197
198    /**
199     * This and {@link #additionalChecks additionalChecks} are the two methods
200     * involved in implementing a validator for the language.
201     *<p>
202     * Each method should simply return normally if its checks pass, or throw
203     * an (ideally informative) exception if not. The work is split into two
204     * methods (which need not both be supplied) because PostgreSQL does not
205     * guarantee that the validator fully ran at the time of creating any
206     * routine. Therefore, while PL/Java will normally call both methods during
207     * validation when a function or procedure is being created, it also will
208     * call {@link #essentialChecks essentialChecks} at runtime, in advance of
209     * calling {@link #prepare prepare}, so this is the place to put checks that
210     * are necessary to support assumptions {@code prepare} relies on.
211     *<p>
212     * For Glot64, this method does nothing. The only check needed at validation
213     * time is whether the source text successfully 'compiles', and the
214     * {@code prepare} method will have to compile the code anyway, so including
215     * that check here would be redundant. It can be included in
216     * {@code additionalChecks}, so a user has useful feedback at create time.
217     * @param subject the proposed Glot64 routine to be validated
218     * @param checkBody whether to perform all checks. When false, depending on
219     * details of the language being implemented, some checks may need to be
220     * skipped. PostgreSQL can call validators with {@code checkBody} false at
221     * odd times, such as during {@code pg_restore} or {@code pg_upgrade}, when
222     * not everything in the database may be as the full suite of checks would
223     * expect.
224     */
225    @Override
226    public void essentialChecks(
227        RegProcedure<PLJavaBased> subject, boolean checkBody)
228    throws SQLException
229    {
230        System.out.printf("%s essentialChecks: checkBody %s\n",
231            subject, checkBody);
232    }
233
234    /**
235     * This and {@link #essentialChecks essentialChecks} are the two methods
236     * involved in implementing a validator for the language.
237     *<p>
238     * Each method should simply return normally if its checks pass, or throw
239     * an (ideally informative) exception if not. See
240     * {@link #essentialChecks essentialChecks} for more on why there are two
241     * methods.
242     *<p>
243     * For Glot64, this is the only method that really checks anything, namely,
244     * that the source text can be 'compiled'. That is work the {@code prepare}
245     * method must do when it is called anyway, so there is nothing to gain by
246     * having it redundantly done in {@code essentialChecks}. Doing it here at
247     * {@code CREATE} time, though, gives helpful feedback to a user.
248     * @param subject the proposed Glot64 routine to be validated
249     * @param checkBody whether to perform all checks. When false, depending on
250     * details of the language being implemented, some checks may need to be
251     * skipped. PostgreSQL can call validators with {@code checkBody} false at
252     * odd times, such as during {@code pg_restore} or {@code pg_upgrade}, when
253     * not everything in the database may be as the full suite of checks would
254     * expect.
255     */
256    @Override
257    public void additionalChecks(
258        RegProcedure<PLJavaBased> subject, boolean checkBody)
259    throws SQLException
260    {
261        System.out.printf("%s additionalChecks: checkBody %s: ",
262            subject, checkBody);
263
264        /*
265         * For Glot64, 'compiling' is purely a matter of string transformation
266         * and has no interaction with database state, so the judgment call can
267         * be made (as here) to include this check even when checkBody is false.
268         */
269        compile(subject.src());
270
271        System.out.printf("ok\n");
272    }
273
274    /**
275     * Prepares an executable template for a routine (a function or procedure).
276     *<p>
277     * The parameter to this method is a {@link RegProcedure}, carrying a
278     * {@link PLJavaBased PLJavaBased} memo. The {@code RegProcedure} exposes
279     * the PostgreSQL catalog information for the routine, and the memo provides
280     * some more information computed and cached by PL/Java. However, at this
281     * stage, no information from any specific call site is presented.
282     *<p>
283     * For example, the memo describes the number, names,  and types of the
284     * routine's inputs (all of its declared parameters that have mode
285     * {@code IN}, {@code INOUT}, or {@code VARIADIC}) and outputs (the ones
286     * with mode {@code INOUT}, {@code OUT}, or {@code TABLE}), each set
287     * presented in the simple form of a {@link TupleDescriptor}.
288     *<p>
289     * Because this information is based only on the routine's declaration,
290     * these tuple descriptors are called {@code inputsTemplate} and
291     * {@code outputsTemplate}. They may contain entries with polymorphic types
292     * that will be resolved to concrete types at a given call site (and
293     * possibly to different concrete types at a different call site). The
294     * {@link BitSet BitSet}s {@code unresolvedInputs} and
295     * {@code unresolvedOutputs} indicate which positions must be resolved
296     * later. If the bit sets are empty, the template {@code TupleDescriptor}s
297     * are already complete descriptors of the inputs and outputs that will be
298     * seen at call sites.
299     *<p>
300     * This method should precompute whatever it can based on the routine's
301     * catalog declaration and the template tuple descriptors only, and return
302     * a {@link Template} instance, which must depend only on this information,
303     * as it will be cached with the {@code RegProcedure} itself, independently
304     * of any call site.
305     *<p>
306     * At a call site, the {@code Template} instance's {@code specialize} method
307     * will be called on a {@link Lookup Lookup} object (conventionally called
308     * {@code flinfo}) representing the call site. At that stage, more specific
309     * information is available, such as fully-resolved {@code TupleDescriptor}s
310     * for the inputs and outputs, and which argument expressions at that call
311     * site have stable values that will not vary in succesive calls made at
312     * that site. The {@code specialize} method should use that information to
313     * generate and return a {@link Routine Routine}, a fully-resolved object
314     * with a {@code call} method ready to be cached at that call site and used
315     * for (possibly many) calls made there.
316     *<p>
317     * When the routine has no polymorphic inputs or outputs, as reported by
318     * empty {@code unresolvedInputs} and {@code unresolvedOutputs} bit sets
319     * at the {@code prepare} stage, a final {@code Routine} can be generated
320     * at that stage, and the {@code Template} returned by {@code prepare} can
321     * simply return it unconditionally (unless it wants to look at which
322     * input expressions can be treated as stable).
323     *<p>
324     * For each call at a given call site, a {@link Call Call} instance will be
325     * passed (conventionally as {@code fcinfo}) to the generated
326     * {@code Routine}'s {@code call} method. The {@code Call} object bears the
327     * actual {@link TupleTableSlot}s from which the routine will fetch its
328     * arguments and to which it will (XXX when implemented) store its
329     * result(s).
330     */
331    @Override
332    public Template prepare(RegProcedure<PLJavaBased> target)
333    throws SQLException
334    {
335        PLJavaBased memo = target.memo();
336
337        BitSet unresolvedIn  = memo.unresolvedInputs();
338        BitSet unresolvedOut = memo.unresolvedOutputs();
339
340        System.out.printf(
341            "%s prepare():\n" +
342            "inputsTemplate   : %s\n" +
343            "unresolvedInputs : %s\n" +
344            "outputsTemplate  : %s\n" +
345            "unresolvedOutputs: %s\n",
346
347            target,
348
349            memo.inputsTemplate()
350                .stream().map(Attribute::type).collect(toList()),
351
352            unresolvedIn,
353
354            /*
355             * Unlike inputsTemplate, outputsTemplate can return null. That can
356             * happen for two reasons: (1) the routine is declared VOID and no
357             * outputs are needed, or (2) it is declared RECORD and will rely on
358             * an output column definition list at every call site, so there is
359             * no outputsTemplate to examine in advance.
360             */
361            ofNullable(memo.outputsTemplate())
362                .map(t ->
363                    t.stream()
364                    .map(Attribute::type)
365                    .map(Object::toString)
366                    .collect(toList())
367                    .toString())
368                .orElse("null"),
369
370            /*
371             * It's also possible for unresolvedOutputs to be null, in the
372             * declared-RECORD-so-nothing-is-known-yet case. (In the VOID case,
373             * it will just be an empty BitSet, meaning no outputs need to be
374             * resolved, just as an empty BitSet would mean any other time. That
375             * makes it simple to test for canSkipResolution, as shown below.)
376             */
377            Objects.toString(unresolvedOut)
378        );
379
380        boolean canSkipResolution =
381            unresolvedIn.isEmpty()
382                &&  null != unresolvedOut  &&  unresolvedOut.isEmpty();
383
384        /*
385         * For this 'language', all compilation can be done early; it does not
386         * need to see resolved type descriptors from flinfo at a call site.
387         */
388        String compiled = compile(target.src());
389
390        /*
391         * This will be the Template object, cached with the RegProcedure.
392         */
393        return flinfo ->
394        {
395            /*
396             * It might be interesting to know which arguments are 'stable' at
397             * this 'flinfo' call site, meaning they will have the same values
398             * in any number of upcoming calls at this site. In a realistic
399             * case, there might be certain arguments we'd be interested in
400             * precomputing values from, and we can use a BitSet to indicate
401             * which arguments we'd like to know the stability of, and the set
402             * returned from inputsStable will show the subset of those
403             * positions where stable expressions have been passed. For this
404             * example, we'll start by setting all bits [0,nargs) and thus ask
405             * about all the arguments.
406             */
407            TupleDescriptor inDescriptor = flinfo.inputsDescriptor();
408            int nargs = inDescriptor.size();
409            BitSet maybeStable = new BitSet(nargs);
410            maybeStable.set(0, nargs);
411
412            System.out.printf(
413                "%s Template.specialize():\n" +
414                "inputsDescriptor : %s\n" +
415                "inputsAreSpread  : %s\n" +
416                "stableInputs     : %s\n" +
417                "outputsDescriptor: %s\n",
418
419                target,
420
421                inDescriptor.stream().map(Attribute::type).collect(toList()),
422
423                flinfo.inputsAreSpread(),
424
425                flinfo.stableInputs(maybeStable),
426
427                /*
428                 * Above, outputsTemplate could return null for two reasons.
429                 * The second reason no longer applies; if the routine is
430                 * declared RECORD and this call site has no column definition
431                 * list, outputsDescriptor throws an exception. But a null
432                 * return is still possible in the VOID case.
433                 *
434                 * Why not an empty descriptor for VOID? An empty descriptor
435                 * really occurs if a function returns t where t is a
436                 * zero-column composite type. Odd thing to do, but allowed.
437                 */
438                ofNullable(flinfo.outputsDescriptor())
439                    .map(d ->
440                        d.stream()
441                        .map(Attribute::type)
442                        .map(Object::toString)
443                        .collect(toList())
444                        .toString())
445                    .orElse("null")
446            );
447
448            /*
449             * This will be the Routine object, cached with the call site.
450             */
451            return fcinfo ->
452            {
453                Call.Context cx = fcinfo.context();
454
455                String subifc = ofNullable(cx)
456                    .map(c -> c.getClass().getInterfaces()[0].getSimpleName())
457                    .orElse("null");
458
459                String maybeAtomic =
460                    (cx instanceof Call.Context.CallContext)
461                    ? String.format("atomic: %s\n",
462                        ((Call.Context.CallContext)cx).atomic())
463                    : "";
464
465                System.out.printf(
466                    "%s Routine.call():\n" +
467                    "collation: %s\n" +
468                    "context: %s\n%s" +
469                    "result:\n%s",
470                    target,
471                    fcinfo.collation(),
472                    subifc, maybeAtomic,
473                    compiled // here we 'execute' the 'compiled' routine :)
474                );
475            };
476        };
477    }
478
479    @Override
480    public void essentialTriggerChecks(
481        RegProcedure<PLJavaBased> subject, boolean checkBody)
482    throws SQLException
483    {
484        System.out.printf("essentialTriggerChecks: ");
485        essentialChecks(subject, checkBody);
486    }
487
488    @Override
489    public void additionalTriggerChecks(
490        RegProcedure<PLJavaBased> subject, boolean checkBody)
491    throws SQLException
492    {
493        System.out.printf("additionalTriggerChecks: ");
494        additionalChecks(subject, checkBody);
495    }
496
497    @Override
498    public TriggerTemplate prepareTrigger(RegProcedure<PLJavaBased> target)
499    throws SQLException
500    {
501        System.out.printf(
502            "%s prepareTrigger():\n",
503            target
504        );
505
506        String compiled = compile(target.src());
507
508        return trigger ->
509        {
510            System.out.printf(
511                "%s TriggerTemplate.specialize():\n" +
512                "name      : %s\n" +
513                "relation  : %s\n" +
514                "function  : %s\n" +
515                "called    : %s\n" +
516                "events    : %s\n" +
517                "scope     : %s\n" +
518                "enabled   : %s\n" +
519                "internal  : %s\n" +
520                "arguments : %s\n" +
521                "columns   : %s\n" +
522                "when      : %s\n" +
523                "tableOld  : %s\n" +
524                "tableNew  : %s\n" +
525                "isClone   : %s\n" +
526                "constraint: %s\n" +
527                "deferrable: %s\n" +
528                "initiallyDeferred: %s\n" +
529                "constraintTable  : %s\n" +
530                "constraintIndex  : %s\n",
531                target,
532                trigger.name(), trigger.relation(), trigger.function(),
533                trigger.called(), trigger.events(), trigger.scope(),
534                trigger.enabled(), trigger.internal(),
535                trigger.arguments(),
536                projectionListNames(trigger.columns()),
537                ofNullable(trigger.when())
538                    .map(xml ->
539                    {
540                        try
541                        {
542                            return xml.getString();
543                        }
544                        catch ( SQLException e )
545                        {
546                            return e.toString();
547                        }
548                    }).orElse("null"),
549                trigger.tableOld(),
550                trigger.tableNew(),
551                trigger.isClone(),
552                trigger.constraint(),
553                trigger.deferrable(), trigger.initiallyDeferred(),
554                trigger.constraintRelation(), trigger.constraintIndex()
555            );
556
557            return triggerData ->
558            {
559                System.out.printf(
560                    "%s TriggerFunction.apply():\n" +
561                    "called       : %s\n" +
562                    "event        : %s\n" +
563                    "scope        : %s\n" +
564                    "relation     : %s\n" +
565                    "trigger      : %s\n" +
566                    "triggerTuple : %s\n" +
567                    "newTuple     : %s\n" +
568                    "updatedCols  : %s\n" +
569                    "result:\n%s",
570                    target,
571                    triggerData.called(), triggerData.event(),
572                    triggerData.scope(), triggerData.relation(),
573                    triggerData.trigger(),
574                    slotListNamesTypes(triggerData.triggerTuple()),
575                    slotListNamesTypes(triggerData.newTuple()),
576                    projectionListNames(triggerData.updatedColumns()),
577                    compiled // here we 'execute' the 'compiled' routine :)
578                );
579
580                return null; // in real life this suppresses triggering event
581            };
582        };
583    }
584
585    /**
586     * This method handles 'compiling' Glot64 source code (which is Base64)
587     * into its 'compiled' form, which is ASCII and easier to read than the
588     * source.
589     *<p>
590     * It is factored out here so it can also be conveniently used at validation
591     * time.
592     *<p>
593     * The longwinded style with explicit {@code newEncoder}/{@code newDecoder}
594     * calls is used to get strict checking (instead of lax character
595     * substitution) from the encoder/decoder, to give the most, shall we say,
596     * thorough feedback to the user.
597     */
598    public static String compile(String sourceText) throws SQLException
599    {
600        try
601        {
602            CharBuffer cb = CharBuffer.wrap(sourceText);
603            ByteBuffer bb = US_ASCII.newEncoder().encode(cb);
604            bb = Base64.getDecoder().decode(bb);
605            cb = US_ASCII.newDecoder().decode(bb);
606            return cb.toString();
607        }
608        catch ( CharacterCodingException | IllegalArgumentException e )
609        {
610            throw new SQLSyntaxErrorException(
611                "compiling glot64 code: " + e, "42601", e);
612        }
613    }
614
615    private static String projectionListNames(Projection td)
616    {
617        return
618            ofNullable(td)
619                .map(d ->
620                    d.stream()
621                    .map(Attribute::name)
622                    .map(Object::toString)
623                    .collect(toList())
624                    .toString())
625                .orElse("null");
626    }
627
628    private static String slotListNamesTypes(TupleTableSlot tts)
629    {
630        return
631            ofNullable(tts)
632                .map(s ->
633                    s.descriptor().stream()
634                    .map(a->a.name() + ":" + a.type().qualifiedName())
635                    .collect(toList())
636                    .toString())
637                .orElse("null");
638    }
639}
